Award.AwardTitle: Rigidity and superrigidity in von Neumann algebras
Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of this project is to develop new techniques to study and classify von Neumann algebras arising from groups and actions of groups on probability spaces. The proposed research is motivated by the following fundamental question: how much does a von Neumann algebra remember about the group or group action it was constructed from? This question is intimately related to topics in ergodic theory, group theory and descriptive set theory and has recently generated a flurry of interactions with these fields. During the last decade, Popa's deformation/rigidity theory has led to a wealth of rigidity results. These show that a lot of information about groups or group actions can be read by looking at their von Neumann algebras. Recently, the first classes of group actions and groups which are von Neumann superrigid (i.e. which can be entirely reconstructed from their von Neumann algebras) have been discovered. The investigator intends to continue this line of research and develop new methods to extend the scope of rigidity and superrigidity in von Neumann algebras. The proposed research will combine von Neumann algebraic techniques from deformation/rigidity theory with tools from ergodic theory and representation theory of groups. The investigator expects that the proposed research project will also lead to new interactions between these fields and the theory of von Neumann algebras.

In mathematics, rigidity refers to an ideal-like situation in which understanding part of the structure of an object is enough to unravel the object's entire structure. Over the years, rigidity results have appeared in various areas of mathematics. Recently, deformation/rigidity theory has cemented the role of von Neumann algebras as a fertile framework for studying rigidity. It has led to the resolution of many long-standing problems not only in von Neumann algebras, but in orbit equivalence ergodic theory and descriptive set theory as well. In the coming years, the theory has great potential to find new applications to these areas as well as surprising connections with other fields. The proposed project is well suited to the training of graduate students. It includes many directions of study and open problems that sprung from deformation/rigidity theory. The results deriving from this project will be broadly disseminated through publications, lecture series, and talks. The investigator intends to continue promoting interactions between von Neumann algebras and other subjects within the broad theme of rigidity through active involvement in the organization of conferences and seminars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the award period, the principal investigator (Adrian Ioana) has continued his work in von Neumann Algebras, the study of “algebras” of operators which emerged from quantum mechanics in the 1930s, and in Ergodic Theory, the study of “volume” (or “measure”) preserving dynamics which emerged from statistical physics about 100 years ago. 

Ioana’s work focused on two main topics: the study of orbits of measure preserving actions, and the classification of von Neumann algebras. To briefly explain the results obtained on the first topic, image that we are given the sphere of radius 1 centered at the origin, and we pick a rotation about a given axis. For simplicity and in order to avoid non-interesting periodic dynamics, assume that the rotation takes an arbitrary point P=P(0) on the sphere and rotates it around the z-axis by an angle which an irrational multiple of pi. We are now at a new point P(1) on the sphere. By repeating this procedure (forwards and backwards) we get infinitely many points, …P(-2), P(-1), P(0), P(1), P(2)…. This is the so-called orbit of the point P under the rotation. Ioana’s work explores the following question: to what extent does the orbit of a typical point P depend on the chosen rotation? It turns out, following a classical result of Dye (1959), that the typical orbits will look the same for any two rotations, even if the angles of rotation are different! However, the situation becomes a lot more interesting, if instead of one rotation, one considers a pair rotations on the sphere.   Once again, if we pick a point P on the sphere and apply repeatedly one of the two rotations (or their inverses), we obtain an infinite orbit of points. Ioana’s work uncovered the following surprising rigidity phenomenon: in many cases, if we start with two different pairs of rotations on the sphere, then the typical orbits will look completely different. In mathematical terms, the difference stems from the fact that one rotation generates a commutative group, whereas a pair of rotations typically generates a non-commutative free group.

In order to prove such a result, Ioana showed that certain operators  (which can be thought of as infinite matrices) have a “spectral gap”: their eigenvalues are numbers between 0 and 1, but which cannot be too close to 1. Such “spectral gap” results are of a broader importance. Indeed, they can be used to give new interesting examples of “expander” graphs. These are infinite families of highly connected sparse finite graphs that are of central importance in computer science. 

Ioana’s research has resulted in 10 publications, available free of charge at arxiv.org and on his website. Ioana has written an expository paper which presents the latest advances in his area to the larger mathematical community. The results have been widely disseminated through over 20 talks at various international research conferences, workshops, and seminars. These include a 6-hour lecture series in 2015 aimed at introducing graduate students to Ioana’s work. Ioana has also given two talks in his department’s undergraduate colloquium, and has co-written the exam for several editions of an annual math competition for high-school students in the San Diego area.

During the award period, Ioana has mentored three PhD students. Two of them have advanced to candidacy, and should receive their degrees in the next couple of years. In addition, Ioana has mentored an extremely successful postdoctoral scholar, who is currently holding a prestigious research position at a university in Bordeaux, France.
